easy_words.algorithm: A step-by-step procedure or formula for solving a problem.
easy_words.binary: A number system with a base of 2, using only 0 and 1.
easy_words.compiler: A program that translates high-level programming code into machine code.
easy_words.database: A structured set of data stored electronically.
easy_words.encryption: The process of converting information into a code to prevent unauthorized access.
easy_words.function: A named section of a program that performs a specific task.
easy_words.hardware: The physical components of a computer system.
easy_words.software: The programs and applications that run on a computer.
easy_words.interface: The point of interaction between the user and the computer or between different systems.
easy_words.memory: The component of a computer that stores data for short-term use.
easy_words.network: A collection of interconnected computers and devices.
easy_words.programming: The process of writing code to instruct a computer.
easy_words.terminal: A text-based interface for interacting with a computer.
easy_words.variable: A storage location identified by a memory address and an associated symbolic name.
easy_words.abstraction: The process of simplifying complex systems to focus on relevant details.
easy_words.analysis: The process of examining and evaluating data or information.
easy_words.assembly: A low-level programming language with a strong correspondence between its instructions and the architecture's machine code instructions.
easy_words.iteration: The repetition of a process or set of instructions in a computer program.
easy_words.machine: A device consisting of interconnected components that manipulate data according to a set of instructions.
easy_words.module: A self-contained unit of software that performs a specific task.
easy_words.protocol: A set of rules or conventions governing communication between computers.
easy_words.recursion: A programming technique in which a function calls itself directly or indirectly.
easy_words.validation: The process of checking if something complies with a certain set of rules or standards.
easy_words.thread: The smallest sequence of programmed instructions that can be managed independently by a scheduler.
easy_words.waterfall: A linear and sequential approach to software development.
easy_words.agile: A flexible and iterative approach to software development.
easy_words.property: A characteristic or attribute of an object in programming.
easy_words.heuristic: A technique or method that efficiently solves a problem but is not guaranteed to be optimal or perfect.
easy_words.namespace: A container that holds a set of identifiers to avoid naming conflicts between different parts of a program.

medium_words.python: A high-level programming language known for its readability and simplicity.
medium_words.kernel: The core component of an operating system.
medium_words.query: A request for data or information from a database.
medium_words.cache: A hardware or software component that stores data to serve future requests more quickly.
medium_words.syntax: The set of rules that dictate how programs written in a programming language are interpreted.
medium_words.valgrind: A programming tool for memory debugging, memory leak detection, and profiling.
medium_words.makefile: A special file that contains rules on how to compile and link a program.
medium_words.swift: A programming language developed by Apple for iOS, macOS, watchOS, and tvOS development.
medium_words.pixel: The smallest unit of a digital image.
medium_words.server: A computer or system that manages network resources and provides services to other computers.
medium_words.import: In programming, the inclusion of external modules or libraries into a program.
medium_words.export: In programming, making a function, variable, or module available to the outside world.
medium_words.sprint: A short, time-boxed period during which a specific work has to be completed and made ready for review.
medium_words.unit: A module of a program that represents a single coherent function.
medium_words.script: A sequence of instructions written in a programming language for execution by a computer.
medium_words.cipher: An algorithm for performing encryption or decryption.
medium_words.struct: A composite data type in programming that groups variables under a single name.
medium_words.plugin: A software component that adds specific features to an existing computer program.
medium_words.switch: A control statement that selects one of many code blocks to be executed.
medium_words.source: The human-readable version of a program's code.
medium_words.vector: A dynamic array or a one-dimensional array in programming.
medium_words.packet: A unit of data that travels across a network.
medium_words.method: A function that is associated with an object in object-oriented programming.
medium_words.object: A self-contained unit that consists of both data and procedures to manipulate the data.
medium_words.socket: An endpoint for sending or receiving data across a computer network.
medium_words.array: A collection of elements, each identified by an index or a key.
medium_words.alias: An alternative name for a variable, function, or object.
medium_words.token: A single unit of lexical meaning in a programming language.
medium_words.index: A position or pointer pointing to a specific element in a data structure.

hard_words.queue: A data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle.
hard_words.api: Application Programming Interface - a set of rules for building software applications.
hard_words.node: In computing, a node can be a device or data point in a larger network.
hard_words.svg: Scalable Vector Graphics - an XML-based vector image format.
hard_words.loop: A sequence of instructions that is continually repeated until a certain condition is reached.
hard_words.git: A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
hard_words.html: Hypertext Markup Language - the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.
hard_words.xml: eXtensible Markup Language - a markup language that defines rules for encoding documents in a format readable by both humans and machines.
hard_words.php: Hypertext Preprocessor - a server-side scripting language widely used in web development.
hard_words.http: Hypertext Transfer Protocol - the foundation of data communication on the World Wide Web.
hard_words.tcp: Transmission Control Protocol - one of the main protocols in the Internet protocol suite.
hard_words.udp: User Datagram Protocol - a connectionless protocol used for data transmission.
hard_words.css: Cascading Style Sheets - a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML.
hard_words.bit: The basic unit of information in computing and digital communications.
hard_words.byte: A unit of digital information that consists of 8 bits.
hard_words.bash: Bourne Again SHell - a command processor that typically runs in a text window.
hard_words.java: A high-level, class-based, object-oriented programming language.
hard_words.lint: A tool that analyzes source code to flag programming errors, bugs, stylistic errors, and suspicious constructs.
hard_words.test: A procedure intended to establish the quality, performance, or reliability of something.
hard_words.shell: A user interface for access to an operating system's services.
hard_words.heap: A region of a computer's memory used for dynamic memory allocation.
hard_words.link: A reference or navigation element that allows you to navigate from one document to another or from one part of a document to another.
hard_words.graph: A collection of nodes and edges that connect pairs of nodes in a network.
hard_words.hash: A function that converts input data (or 'message') into a fixed-size string of bytes.
hard_words.ram: Random Access Memory - a type of computer memory that is used to store data that is being actively used or processed.
hard_words.ssh: Secure Shell - a cryptographic network protocol for operating network services securely over an unsecured network.
hard_words.url: Uniform Resource Locator - a reference or address used to access resources on the internet.
hard_words.vim: A highly configurable text editor often used for programming.
